nodes.bodyText:
LinkedIn pulls weekly from open source and deploys into production. LinkedIn (and others who may pull regularly from open source pinot) can get some information of what may break the deployment (even if retro-fixed).
It is a good practice to have release notes that describe the upgrade scenarios that may break. If we have good labels on PRs, whoever cuts the release can compile the release notes easily.
It hopefully makes the reviewers think whether something may break compatibility.

nodes.bodyText: This bullet is not very intuitive to me. Are we saying that if you broke zero downtime upgrade earlier and now fixing it as part of this PR then label it backward incompat? That should be backward compatible. We recently had this scenario.

nodes.bodyText:
The idea is that this flagged somehow for people to take a look at. A release may have happened between the two commits, in which case some action is needed (that happened a couple of releases ago). Or, at the minimum, the other PR needs to be flagged as backward incompat.
I am open to suggestions, but the goal is for us to know the commits during which zero downtime upgrades are broken, or if this is broken intentionally (should not happen, so needs review).

Even with the "Things to consider", the release notes section is still just a Yes/No question. When the answer is Yes, better explicitly ask the author to prepare some release notes, to make the release master's life easier.
e.g. (borrowing the norm from Presto)
== RELEASE NOTES ==

General Changes
* ...
* ...

If release note is NOT required, use:
== NO RELEASE NOTE ==
